description: Sum of factorials of the digits of n.
comments: Numbers n such that a(n) = n are known as factorions. It is known that there are exactly four of these [in base 10]: 1, 2, 145, 40585. - _Amarnath Murthy_The sum of factorials of the digits is the same for 0, 1, 2 in any base. - _Alonso del Arte_, Oct 21 2012
links: Harry J. Smith, Table of n, a(n) for n=0..1000
Project Euler Problem 74: Determine the number of factorial chains that contain exactly sixty non-repeating terms. [From Dremov Dmitry (dremovd(AT)gmail.com), May 21 2009]
maple: A061602 := proc(n)        add(factorial(d),d=convert(n,base,10)) ;end proc: # _R. J. Mathar_, Dec 18 2011
mathematica: a[n_] := Total[IntegerDigits[n]! ]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 53}] (* Saif Hakim (saif7463(AT)gmail.com), Apr 23 2006 *)
prog: (PARI) { for (n=0, 1000, a=0; x=n; until (x==0, a+=(x - 10*(x\10))!; x=x\10); write("b061602.txt", n, " ", a) ) } \\ _Harry J. Smith_, Jul 25 2009(MAGMA) a061602:=func< n | n eq 0 select 1 else &+[ Factorial(d): d in Intseq(n) ] >; [ a061602(n): n in [0..60] ]; // _Klaus Brockhaus_, Nov 23 2010
author: _Amarnath Murthy_, May 19 2001
extensions: Corrected and extended by _Vladeta Jovovic_, May 19 2001
Link and amended comment by Mark Hudson (mrmarkhudson(AT)hotmail.com), Nov 12 2004
